ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much Arabic grammar in this course, even as a native speaker. My reading got better, my vocabulary expanded, and I have a new appreciation for the language.
I learned many concepts about Arabic grammar and Islamic theology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: the structure of the course is great (grammar topic followed by group reading), the instructor was great, and the workload was very reasonable (some reading before each class, a very small presentation at some point in the semester, and one final project and exam). Honestly no weaknesses. Easily my favorite class of the year.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'm fairly certain this is the instructor's last year teaching it, so while I loved this class, a class is only as good as the person who teaches it. I think it's a great class to take if you want to improve your Arabic reading without needing a 1.5 credit class that meets every day.
Yes! If youre interested in developing your Arabic grammar skills and or just want to read Arabic Islamic texts.
